reviewText: Let's neglect the fact that the original dev was a huge ♥♥♥♥ to everyone.  Let's neglect the fact he raged like a child for a simple fixable reason and said some messed up things on twitter.  Let's neglect the fact he outright cheated the original music composer out of pay, after he put personal pursuits on hold because he was told he'd get paid.  Let's neglect the fact that the game got taken down off steam, bought out by a new publisher, and brought back to steam.\n\nIts still an obsolete version of Ziggurat.  While there are differences, in just about every regard Ziggurat is a superior game and your money would be better spent on that.  This game was enjoyable for the nonexistant price of a humble bundle game, but I can't recommend spending any more than $5 on this.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Disclaimer: This review is for an Early Access game, which has changed since this review was written. I have no interest in reinvestigating the current situation, so take it with a grain of salt. The developer has released updates since this review was posted.

The game itself is not bad. I've found it decently enjoyable. Not a huge amount of replay value, but I got to the end once. The problem with Paranautical Activity is the developer.

The developers have continuously insulted and mocked people who bought their game. In addition, they have been less than honest. The game was marketed for over a year as having co-op incoming (and as of this review, the store page says the developers are still working on it), yet that feature was suddenly canceled. The developers insist they have been working hard on bugfixes and content updates, yet have not released anything, even missing a promised deadline by over two months (patch is yet to be released as of this review). Furthermore, the devs have been silent on the forums (when not aggresively insulting the people who bought their game) and insist you should visit their website, where they will keep people updated; visiting their webiste reveals no new news in two months, and the last message was just an apology for a delay (that has still not been resolved). And when fans have the nerve to say they aren't being treated fairly? The devs say people are entitled." Do not buy this game
date: do not support this kind of rude immaturity from developers
recommended: do not support Early Access games that are deceptively marketed."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Wow! I did *not* expect this game to be so addictive and absolutely satisfying. A long-overdue and well-executed fast-paced, circle-strafing, old school twitch shooter feel with a lot of elements very much like Binding of Isaac (a very good thing, and I mention the likeness only to its credit.) Different starting characters/builds with different stats and starting weapons to choose from, randomized/procedurally generated rooms and floors, health/armor/gold/bomb drops off enemies, shops on each floor, tons of unique personal upgrades to buy or earn at the end of each floor, etc. With even more content to come, and co-op multiplayer on the way (dear god yes!), I haven't been this pleased with and addicted to any indie title since FTL.

Most importantly, the core controls and mechanics are an absolute joy. The pace and precision of the controls and the action feel absolutely spot-on. This is something many games destined for mediocrity have overlooked in lieu of trying to do everything else. When it comes down to it, the core mechanics, the precision and pacing of the controls of any shooter are at *least* half of what we either enjoy or can't stand about them. And more often than not, we barely even consciously realize that, if at all. Paranautical Activity absolutely nails it in terms of *exactly* how a shooter like this should feel, and it's a feel that is too rare these days. As a pure gaming experience, this one is a huge breath of fresh air. Bravo!

reviewText:
I should probably have seen the Early Access reviews before purchasing it, but this is where you get a bit more savvy about positive reviews than negative ones.

And frankly, this game isn't too bad. It's just not... fun and doesn't feel too interesting. Think Doom and Binding Of Isaac, but with a worse Health system, weapons that feel powerless at times, and surprisingly bad frame drops at times.

Paranautical Activity (Deluxe Atonement, for its re-release after the minor controversy), is a rogue-lite FPS game, that seems to take notes from Doom and Binding Of Isaac. Yet, it seems to do it in ways that work against the game. While it does use some of the things (fast paced shooting, randomized rooms and floors, varying stats on each character), it doesn't use it well.

Weapons feel quite good to use, although some of them feel rather weak. The shotgun, from my point of view, felt like the biggest let-down of all the weapons, with the bow being powerful and one or two-hitting enemies, with no problem.

Power-ups feel nice too but with next to no proper explination as to what they do, when you pick them up, leave you to guess what they do, for whatever situation you're about to plummet into, with said power-up.

Enemies are... alright. Mostly tedious to deal with, since some range from simple fire a bolt

reviewText:
Voxel FPS with Quake-y movement and randomly generated rooms.

Movement is good, but shooting is unsatisfying.  Rooms are randomly generated, but there isn't a lot of variety and floors/runs end up feeling the same in the end.  Menus look rushed/unfinished. Don't buy it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Take Doom, add some roguelike elements, some bosses, items, neon lights, crazy music, and you got Paranautical Activity.

For 10 dollars, it's worth the few hours you will put into it. If you like old shooters where you move fast, and roguelikes, this is for you.

Enemies are all unique, tough the limited content makes it a bit repetitive after 30-ish long playtroughs, given you get fairly far.

Still worth it.

reviewText:
This is an abuse of Early Access system. It is not polished, it has many bugs, it has really poor optimization. And the devs first mocked with people, then mocked with Gabe. then got kicked out, then sold the game to a different publisher in its unfinished state.

Yeah aim of the developers is not reached since they lack basic courtesy. Anyway, what was that aim? It was simply replicating BoI in FPS setting. Shops, bombs, most of the skills and upgrades were designed on this. This is not bad, since BoI is really fun, but this does not add anything original to the genre either. Every addition came from some other roguelike, e.g Ghost from Spelunky. It is good knowing that developers also like the games I like and many likes, but a collection of features from some well known very well executed games to build a buggy, unfinished mess is completely different thing.

What is the original side of the game? To be fair it has two. First, its art style. User interface and menus are poorly designed, and game plays like the worst possible Unity example once can imagine, so expect stutters when passing through different menus. But in game voxel art is not that bad, and it feels unique. Also the soundtracks are not that bad, and distinct from other roguelike games. But being unique is not always a good thing, check some gameplay videos first, you may not like dubstep at the end.

I am not a good FPS player, so I did not reach past floor 3, but it is not necessary to finish the game to see that this game is abandonware. Any obvious no brainer bug will be there until eternity while new publishers find publishing the new version with a gameplay video and a pdf file rather than some content wise and bug crushing patch.

If u LOVE FPS and also LOVE binding of isaac, u may enjoy this a little, if u also are good with ignoring its bugs. If your feeling towards one of those two is more mediocre, u are advised to go and play some other FPS-roguelike. I can also advice you some other FPS roguelikes, since I have tried many:

- Ziggurat
-Tower of Guns
- Fancy Skulls

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nParanautical Activity is a game that combines Doom with Binding of Isaac. Which is a good concept in theory, but it's execution is disappointing. The problem is that it removes most of what makes Doom and other twitch fps so good. It misses cool weapons and enemies. Also the level design is bland. It's basically Binding of Isaacs boxes attached to each other where you clear a room to go to the next one until you find the floor exit. So no keycards and secrets. The room design is really bland. Same goes for the presentation. It's voxel style graphics just don't work for this game. Also the music is annoying. Hopefully in the future some company picks up the concept and does a good execution.

It advertises the difficulty of BoI and Spelunky but in Binding of Isaac you can beat the whole thing with half a heart without taking a hit, it's all skill. This game requires you to be lucky and not get a boss who spawns eight different enemies that shoot projectiles faster than you can move and that you can't possible see at the same time because half of them will be standing behind you at any given moment.

reviewText:
Disclaimer: I love roguelikes of all types, and even I couldn't even enjoy this game.

I thought maybe I'd give this game a shot, considering the hype surrounding it because of that dude.  Was hoping it'd be some kind of gem, something truly magical where I could understand why he was so upset.  I always try to refrain from crapping on other games because I KNOW how much work and love and time goes into them... but this game is bad.  The UI, the artwork, the generic electronic soundtrack, nothing meshes well, or feels like it belongs in the same universe.

Gameplay wise, the movement speed is wonky and floaty, not in a good quake 3 sorta way.  There's almost zero weight or feel to anything, no way to tell how big explosion radius are, melee weapons are nearly useless, weapons dont feel good to use; I'm looking for redeeming qualities and I can't seem to find any; This game is an idea, it should still be in early access because it lacks zero finesse, polish, character or even just reason to play it.

There's an entire steam store full of roguelikes and roguetypes that are worth your money, Tower of Guns  does a better job of what this game is trying to do, go play that instead. Do not buy this game, it's passable at best, do not give in to the hype.

reviewText: Paranautical Activity was obviously intended to be some mixture of a 3D Binding of Isaac clone with Painkiller, and for the most part it succeeds in that. Player movement is fast and fluid, there's an interesting variety of weapons, and it offers a nice challenge and degree of skill-based gameplay. It lacks enough enemy and room randomization to have huge staying power as a roguelike, but what content there is definitely justifies the sale or bundle price if you're into the roguelike FPS subgenre. It's not as good as Ziggurat but better than heavy bullets. Voxel graphics look decent, soundtrack is pretty crappy but easy to ignore or mute, I haven't encountered any major bugs, overall I'm pretty pleased with it. Paranautical Activity may not be a great indie game, but it's a solid one, and for the reasonable price of admission I think that's enough.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nUnfortunately, I can't recommend this game. The developers advertised the game as having certain prominent features upcoming for several months after they had cancelled development, leading to people buying the game under false pretences. Of course, early access games are always a risk, and things can change, but to continue promising a feature long after they have given up on it is not something that should be accepted or encouraged, even for an Early Access game. That isn't part-and-parcel of what we should accept from early access, it's outright misleading, and an abuse of the Early Access system.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game has never really seen love. Just as the developers have never really shown love and in the middle of this conflict between the players and the developers is a game that had unlimited potential. It's a sad sight to see it die over something as lame as the dev's folding on the co-op support. For me personally, no biggie, yeah it sucks but that just means devs need to step up and deliver something spectacular to their backers for their own short commings on their promises.

I understand the trials and tribulations that a developer goes through to see their vision come to life, another reason why it is sad to see it die but this is still no reason the devs need to go on the offensive or even the defensive as the backlash should have been expected from the community. A more inteligent tact would have been to go back to the drawing board, like maybe consider scrapping their developed engine because of it's short commings and using an outside engine, as there are a lot of free ones to choose from. The point is that, there were alternatives to how this could've been handled, but instead of putting their energy into fixing it, their efforts went into some kind of 'fight the community' damage control and broke it so bad that it is now unfixable. Thus, the world is less one good game.

In all, the game wasn't half bad. It's a great idea but it needs a lot of polishing, the random generating algorithms need fixing and even though, technically that this game is still in early access (of which my review is based on) at this point, needing the polishing and fixes is not a good thing, as I have felt the heart leave this game a long time ago.

I hate saying these words but I cannot recommend"."

reviewText:
tl;dr: It's a bad game and it's not worth the price, buy Ziggurat instead.

This game is a FPS with fast paced combat and randomly generated maps.
The best way to describe the gameplay would be taking the the movement and gunplay from Quake and putting it in The Binding of Isaac, where you walk through randomly generated mazes constituted by many small arenas linked together.
It's a great idea but unfortunately this game sucks.

Even though the game is randomly generated it gets old really quickly since there isn't that many enemies or rooms. The lack of variety is evident ever since your first playthrough.

Most of the weapons in the game feel rather powerless or too slow. Even when they're actually effective, like the demoman's grenade launcher, they still feel unsatisfying and awkward due to the lack of sound effects and impact. In my opinion this is a huge problem since most of the fun you could have with the game simply vanishes.

There's not much to be said about the graphics and the sound either. It's pretty much what you see on the trailer, except not nearly as exciting.

I also get a terrible headache everytime I spend more than 15 minutes playing it. That doesn't happen when I'm playing Quake or Ziggurat. Go figure.

reviewText: Paranautical Activity: Deluxe Atonement Edition is a rogue-like FPS game that takes elements and gameplay from Doom and Quake and couples them with a game like Binding of Isaac, however quickly falls flat. The game is terribly punishing with your small health pool and terrible weapon selection. The controls and gameplay are designed so that the player has to run around and constantly kite enemies hoping their shots will land and hit the enemies. The controls and gameplay are clunky and all the rooms the player goes through seem so repetitive as they are all boxes with different props and obstacles thrown in.  There are items that you can purchase to upgrade but the game does nothing to tell you what does the item do. Most of the time you just purchase an item only to find out that it has negative effects! Also, the difficulty of the game seems odd, some enemies and bosses are really easy and on the other hand some are really difficult. I did about 10 runs, and they were all very similar just with different bosses and the 2nd level boss usually takes me down each time. Looking at the Steam Achievements looks like only ~15% of the players even made it past Level 2 which just shows you how punishing and difficult this game is.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I feel somewhat silly for writing a review for an early access title with less than an hour spent on it, but I'll go ahead and put my thoughts out there anyway. I think I've cleared enough floors and played enough to really judge my experience.

This title aspires to be a throwback to the '90s with an emphasis on constantly moving, strafing around enemies and shooting from the hip. You go from room to room, kill all the enemies within and make it to the boss of the floor before taking the elevator down to the next. Repeat this many times over, with the rooms that you fight in seeming very much the same and the annoying music blaring at all times.

That is Paranautical Activity in a nutshell.
A rougelike take on Doom/Quake this is not. In fact, with all the open seeming environments I was stuck in, it felt more like a grossly simplified voxel take on Unreal Tournament with much less mayhem and enjoyment. Needless to say, I don't quite like this game at the present. It may change for the better due to it being early access, but I think the core designs are already in place and the devs won't flip turn them upside down anytime in the future.

At the very least, I didn't pay full price (a whopping $10) for this. I might be a touch more upset in writing this if I did.
But it WAS the thing I was most looking forward to in the bundle, though...

In closing, I wish the devs the best in improving this...experience and will give future players some advice.
Do not stop strafing, ever. Pick the Tank class if you want a glorious boomstick. The David Bowie class does not have an ultimate move where he transforms into Ziggy Stardust and shoots lasers from a guitar.
That is all.

reviewText:
Paranautical Activity is a dungeon crawler FPS with arcade elements, it shares trashy dubstep music and voxel graphic with Dead Bits, the level construction and power ups with The Binding of Isaac and the fast paced gameplay with DooM and Unreal.

Just like in The Binding of Isaac, this game plays on several different floors, each with rooms that have to be cleared before proceeding into the next room, each floor with two bosses, one of which is optional and rewards the player with an additional power-up.

The graphic is quite simplistic, yet is nicely colourful and blends well with the very arcadish sound effects and the not-deplorable dubstep soundtrack.
Regarding the soundtrack... I can't abstain from admitting that the quality isn't great: it's dubstep, raw, crude, pumping and absolutely videogame-like". The final product is an OST that is hardly playable outside of the game
date: but if you let it run on background as you play

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I generally do not write a review for a game that I have not played at least five hours, but I made this an exception due to how easy it is to experience all there is within the first thirty minutes.

I purchased Paranautical Activity out of curiosity during one of the Steam sales event.
I obtained the game under the impression that it could be a nice pass time game allowing me to go on a rampage;
the game definitely delivered in that aspect, I was given an environment and monsters to shoot at.

The problem with this game, however, is the fact that the entire game seems to be just a showcase of an idea.
Due to this very fact, I was no longer able to endure this game past the 25th minute mark.

I do realize that this game is still in early development, but I would in no manner consider this a game.
The definition of providing early access is to allow people to purchase the game and test it for the developers,
with the fundemental qualification for an early access game being having most, if not all, of the core mechanics present.
This was not the case.
This game feels like it is showcasing the classes and the monsters, with overly simplistic menus with very lacking choices.

This game delivered a functioning showcase, as I have yet to encounter a debilitating glitch,
but other than the above point, there are several other problems I would like to point out:

1) The game does not receive updates frequently enough.
Out of the some eight months of owning this game, the game has yet to receive major function and mechanics update.
The update frequency can easily rank just below the notorious Cube World.

2) The classes are extremely unbalanced, for future update reference.
I have been playing tanks most of the petty amount of time I have endured this game,
as I was shown time and time again in the game that tanks somehow have amazing advantage in both offensive and defensive capabilities compared to many others. I could mow down all mobs regardless of the distance with just the shotgun.

3) The game still does not have multiplayer functionality.
The developer's blog did mention encountering problems on December of last year with creating the multiplayer function, but that was seven months ago.

4) Despite randomized, the game has a very limited amount of mobs, rooms, bosses, and items.
As such, the game was not very engaging, as within twenty minutes, the player may have already encountered every single possible instance. Hence why I could not hold my attention onto the game for even 30 minutes.

Until the game performs a major update with multiplayer capability, and also have far more variety in its instances,
I do not recommend purchasing this game.

TL;DR:
Ranging from instance variety and mechanics, the game is too lacking in too many manners.
Until this game has a multiplayer function and an expanded library of instances, this game is not recommended.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Well, take this recomendation with a pinch of salt, the game is still early access (in a very advanced stage as devs say, though). I can't say I totally disliked the game, but there are too many things that wouldn't allow me to raise my thumb for this game. Here's some:

- The overall presentation and menus look very rushed and unpolished, even for an early access game.
- The music, oh god, the music....
- The total lack balance overall. Not only between classes, not only between enemies and you.
- Dying feels often unfair and frustrating. I won't say how many thousands of times I've died in tons of other roguelikes, and yeah, there's a difference between dying by lack of skill and dying because the game is poorly balanced. The second option doesn't make a roguelike good, hard or anything, it makes it an unnecessary pain in the ♥♥♥ that any sane player should avoid.
- No sense of progress at all. TBOI, Rogue legacy, etc.... they have a sense of achievement after each run. Doesn't happen in this game, and that's a no-go for me.

So, I hope you find this list useful, and I really hope the devs work really hard to make a great game, because there's potential.  I haven't been playing too much, so some things could be missing.
Anyway, the game is on Humble Weekly sale for 1$, if you feel curious about it just go and get it, it won't hurt.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nDecent game as it currently stands in its phase of development. It's essentially an 3D FPS Binding of Issac in gameplay sense.  Apparently they are in the works of adding a coop mode and achievements, so that will add some more fun to the game in the future. However, currently there is not much room for replayability other than beating the game mutliple times with different characters.  All characters are unlocked at the beginning, there are no item unlocks for doing certain things, no unlockable bosses, one final boss, and no story.  Played it for about 5 hours and probably won't play again until they further update it. As it stands, great Early Access game and I recommend you getting purchasing it when it is on sale for ~$3 or less!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

[First of all, let me just admit that I know the programmer of the game personally. I talk to him online all the time, and I've hung out with him. This does not affect my opinion of the game in the slightest. If I thought the game was bad, I wouldn't be writing this.]


Paranautical Activity is a first-person shooter roguelike set on a nazi U-Boat. If you like shooters there is plenty here to enjoy, if you like roguelikes there's even more, and no two runs will likely ever be the same. Being a roguelike, each of the eight stages is filled with procedurally generated rooms. These rooms are filled with an increasingly difficult selection of enemies, along with a boss, a sub boss, a shop, and bonus rooms with various bonuses and challenges. Each floor is also a race against the clock to beat the the boss and progress before an unkillable phantom comes to hurry you along under threat of murder.

There are several playable characters, each with unique play styles. Some, such as Gorton, require precision but do crazy amounts of damage; and others, such as Dy-No-Mite, allow for a more loose play style at the cost of self-destructive splash damage. There is a selection of super weapons that range from a ninja sword that wrecks shop up close, a cannon that demolishes most things, and a gun that uses its ammunition to create more health, bombs, and armor.

There is a wide selection of items that can help you along (and more than a few that will make your going much tougher). Some can make you immune to explosions. Some can basically remove the cap on your rate of fire. Some can give you much more health at the cost of your speed. Some can make all floors dark. Some can do nothing other than change your character's injured sound to a selection of girlish Ooches" and "Ouches."

The varied enemy design ranges from rocket-propelled turtles that fire missiles
date: glowing monkeys that jump back and forth between the floor and ceiling
recommended: and sharks that hunger for your feet. Bosses range from a pair of flying eyeballs that divide themselves when they die
hoursPlayed: a battleship with kamikaze planes circling it
voteText: and a nazi scientist that can resurrect the dead.\n\nThough the game doesn't officially release until around halloween
helpfulPercent: the final content patch just went live a few hours ago
votesHelpful: so I feel comfortable finally officially recommending this game to anyone who enjoys the concepts behind it's design. If you like shooters
votesTotal: I recommend this game. If you like roguelikes
votesFunny: I definitely recommend this game. If you like games that marry the two concepts
commentsCount: then I can't imagine why you wouldn't love this game."

reviewText:
The enemys for this game are usually pretty easy and often involve just simply moving left or backwards to get away from most of their attacks but there are other enemys like the skull and the moth that you need to look out for and the skulls are pretty easy too but if you have low speed (and you often will) they can sneak up on you and deal massive damage. The moths are what you need to look out for because there shots home in on you and these shots WILL hit you and the WILL lower your health to zero eventually if you don't concentrate on dodging there shots these two enemys aren't that bad but they're the only really difficult enemys in this game.

Bosses are strange some bosses are easy and basically the only way to get hit by the easy ones is if you stop circle strafing around them.

The only bosses you need to look out for are the ones with homing shots because they fire a lot and if you aren’t glued to a wall and moving fast your dead for sure. The other hard bosses are the ones that melee you because those ones fly right at you and deal damage and if you aren't moving fast and jumping constantly your dead for sure. However if they aren't FLYING towards you and are just something like a skeleton or something they aren't a problem at all.

So bosses and enemys are alright just might need to change a few of their attacks to make the easy ones harder (recommended change) or the hard ones easier (not recommended change)  to stop making the easy boss fights feel like a circle strafing chore.

Now lets look at the bad part. The items often horribly unbalanced and some items being flat out jokes that do almost nothing is AWFUL.

There is one item in this game called Doxxy that will put me off this game until it gets removed completely. The item changes the sound that you hear when you get hit. That’s. It. You went through an entire blue skull room boss fight where it was that moth with homing shots and you barely made it out alive? Well here’s this completely useless item! You saved up all your money to buy an item in the shop? Well this item is free! It's also useless and takes up 1 of 3 slots in the shop! You only get to items in the shop this time! Should have gotten lucky and had a random dice power up drop so you can reroll this item.

There are so many items that just plain suck. The one that flips gravity when you jump (makes the billion jump upgrades useless cuz you can't really jump anymore)
Doxxy
The one that permanently lowers your speed for a couple of very temporary armor pieces (speed is essential if you aren't going fast then you WILL easily get your health gradually lowered to zero by moths and stuff. See above where I mention that speed is important to fight the bosses and enemys.).
Rage which is a damage up when you kill enemys! What could be wrong with that? Well, it's also a damage down. It is many damage downs. Every 10 seconds or so it lowers your damage by 0.083~ I think and when you kill enemys it increases damage by the same amount lowered so if you aren’t constantly instakilling enemys then you are losing damage. You can't insta kill with this item because its lowering your damage.

Not to mention the item pickup tip for rage simply says Damage up for killing enemys" and doesn't mention this damage down I'm glad I looked at the pdf file supplied that explains items. If I hadn't done that I would think this item was good!

Same with Fool
date:
an item of which simply says "doubles damage" on pickup and doesn't mention that enemys deal double damage too! I could imagine myself spending hours ingame with the fool item dying quickly and not realizing it was fool's fault. (Fool is a good item because of an item called kamikaze which turns those normally useless bombs your carrying into armor and deals damage to enemy that melee you. The downside to kamikaze is that it completely removes your health so if you don't have any bombs and you get hit you die. The whole idea behind kamikaze is that if you now spend health to shoot bombs but bombs require so many upgrades that you wouldn't be shooting them even if you didn't have kamikaze.

I would often find myself getting kamikaze and running around with 40 bombs that I wont use because I have 40 health and it would take so long to get me to zero that the final boss is a cakewalk. I could even take fool to insta kill everyone and it would STILL take a long time to die. bombs are more plentiful then hearts as you can blow up explosive barrels get a 3 hp up at almost any time.

The other way of getting health is to take some health upgrades. The two I found were this one that doubles your health but lowers your speed. Because your speed is lower you are going to get hit easier and speed ups are so rare that this is never worth taking. The other just gives you two health and some armor which helps but both of these are nothing compared to kamikaze.

I would say that kamikaze=win and if you don't get it you will have so many awful items thrown at your way that it's basically restart for kamikaze.

I can name a lot more if I look at which item does in the little pdf file that says what every item does but that would be boring to see me explain why almost every item you find is bad.

So a few items are good and the majority are bad.


The point of item systems in roguelikes are that these items change gameplay and keep it interesting and a lot of these items have potential but are so imbalanced that they aren't worth taking and it turns the game into a restart early to get good items fest which is bad because this means that all your runs are the same because your taking the same items every time. This run is the same every time feeling is magnified by the low number of rooms the made for each floor. The number of rooms they made are so low that I found myself memorizing enemy spawn locations in only a few hours of playing.

Because of the sheer amount of bad items in this game the devs have a lot of stuff to fix. I heard that they are spending most of there time right now adding net co-op but I'd say if you wan't to fix this game then ditch the co-op idea for now and spend all your time on balancing these items and removing doxxy.

I got this game on sale for 3 dollars and it's so bad because of the item system. I don't think this game is even worth 3 dollars as pressing the restart button over and over again isnt fun. If I wanted to press the same button over and over again I would just play cookie clicker.

TL;DR /////

Pros
+FOV slider goes from 30 to way to high
+music is nice

Cons
-enemys are easy except for one or 2
-bosses are either easy or really hard and there's only 2 or 3 hard bosses.
-The items are so bad that it encourages restarting
-music is nice but it isn't tied to floors or rooms or anything it's litterally like they just took some youtube playlist and put it in the game. There is no boss fight music
-I met the system requirements but expereinced harsh lag on lowest graphics because when you kill things the fall into a million cubes some times on later levels these squares become so plentiful that it becomes unbearable
-game sounds are underwhelming. I looked at the credits and it had links to sites like freesounds which makes me feel like they just searched a shotgun sound . mp3 in google  and downloaded the first thing they saw
-item pickup tips are helpful sometimes but other times don't mention a that an item has a secret bad effect. This encorages reading the pdf guide that comes with the game which means playing this game blind is a bad Idea
-speed is essential for dodging and so many items lower this stat that most of the items become useless the game does have good movement but this good movement is gone if you take too many speed down items

Yes
recommended: the only good thing about this game is the fov slider and maybe one or two of the enemys."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Looking for a game that is challenging, but has similar feels to classic first person shooters like Wolfenstein, Doom, and Quake? Then this game is perfect for you. Paranautical activity takes on a perfect random level generation feel like the game Binding of Isaac mixing it with room textures of Wolfenstein (hence the Nazi flags on the wall) making every time you play different from the last. In this game you take on a wide variety of unique enemies, bosses and power-ups as you progress through the games ever changing levels.

The game is as far as I know is still in the early access stage, but it has very high potential for being a very good game and is relatively cheap. So if you want something fun that will get you stuck playing for a while, I encourage getting this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Fun old-style shooter with random powerups which make each playthrough different. Gameplay similar to Quake2/Painkiller/Serious Sam, kiting is a must and prioritizing enemies is key.

Worth every penny, it claims to be in beta but is fully playable right now, and is plenty entertaining. Starts off easy in the difficulty curve, and ramps up as you go deeper into the dungeon. Personally I've found the first few floors to be a cakewalk and the later enemies to be much more challenging.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

FIRST IMPRESSION, I WILL GIVE IT ANOTHER CHANCE AND MAY CHANGE MY MIND DRASTICALLY:

The game is advertised as being a roguelike version of Doom/Quake, but ironically Doom and Quake actually feel more dungeon crawl-y thanks to their intricate maze like level designs and emphasis on strategy and resource management.

Paranautical Activity is basically just a first person Binding of Isaac, in that it just lays out some square rooms at random, populates them with enemies, and calls it a day. In essence, there's really no reason to brag about this game being procedurally generated, because all it really does is switch up the order in which you face the games small pool of monsters while throwing slightly different stats at you.

PA also locks you into every room once you enter it, and won't let you out till you kill every monster inside.  This might have worked for Binding of Isaac since that game was essentially just an arena shooter pretending to be a roguelike, but here it just makes things more mindless. Unlike Doom and Quake where a large part of victory was not only reflexes but picking your battles, escaping at the right time, and thinking strategicly, PA instead reduces things to a guessing game by forcing you to blindly pick which room you enter and than not letting you leave if it turns out doing so might be the smarter strategy.

The controls feel a bit clunky also. I think you have to move for a bit before you accelerate, which feels like ♥♥♥♥ in a game where moving and turning fast could be the difference between life and death. The enemy designs are decent, but nothing special and are never put to much interesting use thanks to the arena based structure of the game.

Aestheticly it's of course as bleh as it looks. Same not-memorable chiptunes you've heard in a million retro indie games, same cuby graphics you've seen in a ton of Minecraft rip offs. I also have no idea why they thought it was a good idea to name their game a pun based on some dumb horror film people will have forgotten about in a few years.

I think the point of all these action roguelikes is that people want a game that feels like a dungeon crawl but with enjoyable skill based combat and that feels new each time. The combat here may be be skill based, but it's rather bland and the games structure doesn't make it feel like a dungeon crawl at all, it also starts to feel repetitive even on the same playthrough. Doom and Quake did every aspect of this game better, and PA doesn't bring anything worthwhile to the table.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Paranautical is a highly addictive game of chance,skill and on the run strategy.
If I were to use another game to describe this one, I would say that Paranautical Activity is a 3D Binding of Isaac like FPS.

This game provides you with a varied selection of starter characters (each with different stats and weapons) so it really caters to the individual's play style. During a runthrough the player can pick up so many items that they will become a personal class of their own, with no resemblance to what they started as.

The player is provided three modes, two of which can be unlocked by completing the standard mode. Paranautical Activity becomes more difficult with each level you complete. Though items you pick up along the way will help you stay ontop of the next levels enemies.

Each playthrough will be a different experience due to the complete random generation of this game. Differently sized levels, spawning different bosses, dropping different loot.

If you are considering buying this game, the answer is yes.

reviewText:
Pros
- Fast-paced, bullet-hell gameplay
- Easy to set up and play
- Tons of replayability
- Lots of unique items
- Variety in classes and weapons
- Fun to figure out what items do
- Procedurally generated floors (no two floors are the same)
- Multiple bosses

- FOV slider

Cons

- Dark rooms do not provide enough light
- Flying skull enemies gang up on you and take chunks out of your health. Can make you feel cheated.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Paranautical Activity is a fast paced FPS Roguelike. It has a difficult learning curve, and the game will kick your ♥♥♥. But kick your ♥♥♥ like your mistress would, you'd come back begging for more.

I initially did not recommend the game, at least for it's price, but recent updates have really fleshed out the game. While still early access, the game is looking at lot more finished now.

The most recent update added a plethora of new items, a new floor, new bosses, and most noteably achievements/unlocks.

I would wholly recommend this game if an FPS Roguelike sounds like your cup of tea.

reviewText:
I can see the logic behind the negative reviews. This game is not for everyone. It requires patience, reflexes and somewhat grinding for achievements - therefore the items.

Now if you are not a fan of rogue-like, action genre, this game wouldn't be the best match for you. If you are, however and want to have some fun, this game suits your needs perfectly.

I will start with saying that the game is really hard. This doesn't make the game frustrating though. After you get the grasp of the mechanics and familiar with the items, it will be only a matter of time to finish the game.

David Bowie (RIP) is a playable character in this game (Though I don't think he would appreciate the choice of soundtrack.).

Gameplay is fast-paced. That means there will be times you won't even understand how you died or took massive amount of damage. So never rely on your health being full. You always need to be alert and keep your reflexes up because the ways to die in this game are just too many.

Like most of the rogue-like dungeon crawlers, RNG factor is significant. Game has six different characters with a huge item pool. There are many things that could make reaching the end a piece of cake. You can get the most OP items on the first floors, you can pray to RNG gods and get some ridiculous stats with the passive items,  you can find the boss room without too much wandering around the rooms and these thing also could make the runs really hard vica-versa.

Simple, pixelated, yet colorful graphics makes the game charming and kind of fits the style of the game itself, in my opinion.

Music is... well, it is dubstep. Depends on your approach to electro music. Although I don't like dubstep myself, it fits the fast-paced theme and makes you randomly jump and shoot to everyone and everywhere, because the groove is real.


Gameplay: 8/10
Graphics 7/10
Music: 7/10
Replay value: 9/10

Overall: 7.5/10, a good game for dungeon crawler or dubstep fans.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Despite the friction between people of the community and people of the development team, this game is quite good.  Steps have been taken to make it what it was set out to be by the developers.

The game on its own merits is very good: Gameplay isn't super unique but it is an enjoyable, fast-paced first-person shooter style rogue-lite.  While the item list at a glance is relatively small the variety of weapons makes it an interesting play.

I wouldn't say it is infinately replayable as the number of item combinations and their affect on your gameplay isn't large, but the game is enjoyable for many hours and is well worth a buy.

I might as well paste a comment I left on a friend's profile as a response to his rightful questioning of my sometimes hyperbolous ♥♥♥. It reads quite a bit like a short review: I finally got around to playing PA and I honestly don't recommend it. Even ignoring the asshattery from the guys who did it, it was much less than what I was hoping for. Objectively it's not all that great. There's a huge lack of sound effects from enemies and part of the fun is that pleasing plonk" that you get when you hit /or kill something in an FPS. It's objectively not all that great of a roguelike either as one of the best things about roguelikes are generally the items and what you can do with them. There is also a sizeable shortage of floors which is again something that roguelikes generally excel at.

I kind of sensed this too. Which is why I was very nervous about the work or lack thereof in the future after they said it was "finished". It really isn't by any decent project standards. Is sad too because I love the aesthetic.

reviewText: If you’ve paid even the slightest attention to games in the past few years, you’re now very aware of what a roguelike is. Even games that have little to anything to do with the traditions of the genre have introduced randomness as a mechanic in order to take advantage of the buzz the term now generations. However, as ubiquitous as roguelikes have become in the last few years on PC, there have been few to try it in an FPS, and fewer still that succeed when they try. Paranautical Activity was actually one of the first as it went through Early Access, but controversy stemming from the game’s original developer delayed its full release to just recently, when a new publisher bought the rights to the title. It’s a good thing too, because Paranautical Activity feels like Doom made in a different age, and certainly deserves recognition for setting the standard of what a procedurally generated shooter should be.\n\nWant to know more? My full review has been posted over at my new home, TechRaptor.net ! http://techraptor.net/content/paranautical-activity-review-explosive-turtle-action

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Firstly, I'd like to point out that this game is still getting more content added to it gradually. So this review is to reflect -current- gameplay and content.

I have greatly enjoyed Paranautival Activity, and it has probably frustrated me about as much as Binding of Isaac has with regards to finding hard bosses, picking up bad items for my build, etc.
If you like games similar to Binding of Isaac or Tower of Guns, this one is a great middle ground. The weapons all have their own advantages (Personally, the sickle is the best weapon in the game hands down) and each item is useful in its own right and can add interesting or frustrating abilities. For example, one item gives you the same jumping mechanic as VVVVVV has, that is, switching gravity and standing on the ceiling instead of jumping. It's cool, but can be a huge pain sometimes.

The enemies are all interesting and difficult in their own right, and certain builds will find some enemies easier than others. I'd give the graphics, gameplay and amount of current content a good 8/10. I'm extremely excited about more stuff being released when the time comes, as I'm sure I'll come back to this game more.
You should give it a try, seriously!

reviewText:
An FPS style binding of isaac esk game that i personally enjoy.

About a year ago, i wouldn't have said that. The games community was a lot smaller. There werent many enemies, and everything just seemed... Unfinished in some way. But that my friends... Is not now. Now i would recommened this game to any/every one of my friends. The game has evolved to the point were it isnt just running around shooting everything that moves, it does involve some strategy.

Example..
Going in to verse a mini boss isnt always the best thing, seeing how a lot of the time it can easily kill you, but at the same time, the item/gold you gain can really benefit you in the future.

I could ramble about what i like about the game from here on, and what i dont like, but i'd rather just give you a list of pros and cons...

Pros:
- Good graphics
- Nice soundtrack
- Unique gameplay
- Fast paced (which not everyone likes)
- Tons of different enemies
- Many bosses (All with unique attack patterns)
- Tons of fun weapons
- David bowie....

Cons:
- Cost.     Dont get me wrong, its not a bad price. But at the same time its not something i would aim for...
- Enemy AI.      Sometimes... They're just so... Stupid...

This game might not appeal to everyone, but if you have the money and generally like Rougue-likes and are also a fan of FPS i recommend this game to you.

The game is great and all that, but it has a couple problems.
-I don't know if anybody else has this problem but I do and it is to do with the performance. It's quite poor on my PC which is a large amount above the minimum requirements yet if I want at least 60 fps I need to turn the game down to either 720p or fastest.
-Lack of multiplayer! Seriously! With all those classes you would think that there would be some form of multiplayer, yet there isn't. Huge wish for it to be there.

Apart from that, the game plays great with the fast-paced shooting and the randomly generated levels make it just a bit more fun and give it a bit more replayability, however I don't see myself playing all that much up until the performance issue is sorted out or a multiplayer mode (One suggestion for that, have it so that you can play with random people, not just friends because I don't have any.) is made.

reviewText:
I wanted to love this game.  I wanted to so badly.

Roguelike?  FPS?  Cool voxel graphics and that 'simplistic but awesome' lighting system reminiscent of games like Quake?  Multiple classes to choose from?  It's just too good to be true, it seems... and sadly, that's the case.

It COULD have been good, could have easily been fixed and polished and balanced just a bit to create a fantastic experience, but in all the months and months I've had this game in its early access phase and even now after this 're-release', it's failed to address any of these issues.  In fact, all it seemingly HAS done is added a couple new enemies, achievements, and made shop prices even more impossibly high.  Great.

The main issue is that it's simply too difficult.  No, NOT haha hardcore fun!" difficult like your Dark Souls or Binding of Isaacs out there

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Buy? Maybe. (Note, this reflects an Early Acess game that will likely change over time, potentially negating this review. Dec 23, 2013).
PA is best described as a rogue-lite FPS, where the gameplay mechanics are boiled down to the near most simple understandings of the FPS model. The goal is to reach lower floors, but I'm not sure if there is an end due to my constant dying. Nagivating each floor is much similar to the Binding of Issac and NES Zelda - Enter a rectangular room and clear the are of enemies before you can advance. The game controls near exactly like the original Painkiller and early entries in the Quake and Unreal Series - fast movement, circle strafing, and bunny hopping. The hook of PA is using your skill to stay alive with your limited health and advancing with a mix of your class weaponry, passive power-ups, and active power-ups.

Classes include Crossbow user, Sickle thrower, Grenade Launcher, a Minigun user and a shotgun user (I forget the names of these classes, except Tank for the shotgun user). Each have their advantages and disadvantages in terms of weapon mechanics, secondary weapons (if any), damage output, range, and health. You can also get other weapons from gift shop if you are able to save up enough cash from them, which is often tough (Weapons seem to cost more than I have ever earned early in game, and when I do save up good funds, I'm usually on level 3-4 where I die). Enemies are varied, some which shoot a single a bullet or two every two seconds, some shooting a continuous hail of bullets, or even those that can nearly teleport to you for melee or enemies that can hop towards you and explode on proximity. What most shooting enemies have in common is that their projectiles aren't hit scan, so it takes timing, skill, and room knowledge to be sucessful. Each floor has a miniboss that usually provides a power-up, money, and sometimes health, weaponry, or items.

The art direction is much like 3D Dot Game Heroes with an interesting lighting selection - where there are very few lights but each projectile also emits projectiles. However, most players will simply say something like DARK MINECRAFT VOXELS WITH GUNS". There is not much sound assets besides gun shots
hoursPlayed: and the player's "Oof!" from being hit. Much of the sound is in the form of a nearly rave-like techno beats that reminds you of other "Futurisitcky" games like Wipeout
voteText: Extreme G

You can skip the majority or at least the remainder of the floor if you desire

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Buy? Maybe. (Note, this reflects an Early Acess game that will likely change over time, potentially negating this review. Dec 23, 2013).
PA is best described as a rogue-lite FPS, where the gameplay mechanics are boiled down to the near most simple understandings of the FPS model. The goal is to reach lower floors, but I'm not sure if there is an end due to my constant dying. Nagivating each floor is much similar to the Binding of Issac and NES Zelda - Enter a rectangular room and clear the are of enemies before you can advance. The game controls near exactly like the original Painkiller and early entries in the Quake and Unreal Series - fast movement, circle strafing, and bunny hopping. The hook of PA is using your skill to stay alive with your limited health and advancing with a mix of your class weaponry, passive power-ups, and active power-ups.

Classes include Crossbow user, Sickle thrower, Grenade Launcher, a Minigun user and a shotgun user (I forget the names of these classes, except Tank for the shotgun user). Each have their advantages and disadvantages in terms of weapon mechanics, secondary weapons (if any), damage output, range, and health. You can also get other weapons from gift shop if you are able to save up enough cash from them, which is often tough (Weapons seem to cost more than I have ever earned early in game, and when I do save up good funds, I'm usually on level 3-4 where I die). Enemies are varied, some which shoot a single a bullet or two every two seconds, some shooting a continuous hail of bullets, or even those that can nearly teleport to you for melee or enemies that can hop towards you and explode on proximity. What most shooting enemies have in common is that their projectiles aren't hit scan, so it takes timing, skill, and room knowledge to be sucessful. Each floor has a miniboss that usually provides a power-up, money, and sometimes health, weaponry, or items.

The art direction is much like 3D Dot Game Heroes with an interesting lighting selection - where there are very few lights but each projectile also emits projectiles. However, most players will simply say something like DARK MINECRAFT VOXELS WITH GUNS". There is not much sound assets besides gun shots

reviewText:
I kind of don't get this game.

From a technical point of view this is a quite fine game. This is a FPS game where every room and every level indeed is randomly generated. We have some patterns like a boss room or a shop room every level although everything else is mostly random.

It's really hard to give a thumbs down to this game as it is technically a good game. This is just my personal opinion.

Pros:
- it's quick
- four distinct character classes - different starting weapons, hit points value, speed and so on
- randomness - after every boss fight we get a random item that changes our stats
- nice graphics, looks like Minecraft on steroids

Cons:
- music is a dubstep mess - personally I don't like such kind of music although someone might find it amusing
- this game is really hard. Maybe not Dark Souls level of hard but still hard
- well character classes are distinct but only Tank starts with 9 hit points which relates to higher survival chance
- I don't see a point in playing this game - this is only imo

So in conclusion - we have a technically decent game that lacks some kind of main motive. Or guts or spirit, whatever we may call it.

If you like randomly generated shooters then go for it, it's ok, it's hard as nails, it's quick as Quake 1 and so on.

I personally cannot recommend this game as it lacks something vital. I can't really describe this value in one words but let's say it this way - this game lacks a value that makes a player want to play this game.

reviewText:
SKIP TO THE BOTTOM FOR TL;DR/PROS AND CONS

Before we begin, I'd just lke to say that I'm fully aware of the drama surrounding this game, and I don't care. Drama doesn't affect the game at all. Now, you might say the fact that the developers lied about multiplayer is something worth noting, but I would say it's not. Don't buy games based on the imaginary multiplayer mode that's not even in the game, this is grade school logic. Alright, without further ado, lets jump into this one.

GAMEPLAY:
So if you buy a rougelike, you're buying it for the gameplay, and Paranautical Activity has a decent ammount of it. Sure, a lot of the rooms and enemies feel very samey, but it's got this addictive trait to it. You basically go room to room shooting various enemy's, whilst collecting items and weapons to bolster your arsenal and defeating bosses. However, this game has absolutely God awful balancing, as if it was barely playtested. At the end of the day, I had a ton of fun with this game, but all that fun will be gone in an instant because of some absolute ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t.

To start, there are certain classes that you cannot pick certain items up with. If you play as the Tank class, you CANNOT pick up ANY items that slow you down at all,  or you will be boned.  The enemies that just relentlessley follow you will be faster than you, and then you'll die, and there's no possible way to avoid this in certain rooms. In fact, for any class, any item that slows you down is a death trap. And some are comically underbalanced, Nine Armor and you get a speed reduction" is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. So since you  can't pick up any items that make you go slower

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI really want to like this game, I really do, but in it's current state and at it's current price, I can't. Paranautical is a rouge-like first person shooter, think Binding of Issac, mixed with Bioshock, which is a beautiful idea, and the 3D pixelated graphics give it a lot of charm, but that's about where charm ends, being a first person shooter, Paranautical Activity is very unforgiving, to put it in perspective I have beat The Binding of Issac multiple times, with multiple charcters, but with Paranautical Activity I'm lucky if I can make it passed the first floor. A lot of the trobule is you are constantly surrounded by enemies, which normally is'nt so bad, but like most FPS when you take damage there is usually a damage indicator, so you know which direction to turn and shoot, not with Paranautical Activity, so you figure that you'll use explosives to handle everything, well that's where another game breaking flaw shows it's ugly head, when you kill an enemy it burst into red pixels that skatter onto the floor and stay there for a few seconds, not bad right? Well every explosion also has a particle effect to the same degree, just orange pixels, so if you kill a group of enemies with an explosion you're in for a lot of particles, and unfourtately the game can't take all the pixels on screen, so it starts to lag real bad, and I know it's not my computer, because I can run games like Skyrim, and Dark Souls with no problems. So there is a lot of good in this game, it's got a great idea, all it needs to do is fix some bugs, but it seems like the developers don't want to fix anything, and until they do, or until they lower the price, I can't reccomend this game, however, if you can find the game for cheap, and you wanna kill a hour or two, pick it up.
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game in it's current state, to put it lightly, is a mess. There is a great concept buried under piles of poor execution and broken promises. The developers also take out anger on the buyers by angrily typing about how our expectations are too high, and how they couldn't possibly finish in time for the deadlines they set for themselves. They also publicly stated that the game was being abandoned. Many promised features aren't going to be included, and they will be putting a 1.0 label on the game.

The game itself is repetitive, glitchy, unbalanced and unpolished. I'd say you should avoid this game like the plague. 2/10.

reviewText:
I'm having a hard time liking this game to be honest, but I'll try to give it the benefit of the doubt.

Despite that notion from myself (Mostly because I paid for the darn thing), I still don't recommend this game.

><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><

Pros:
> interesting graphics

Cons:
> None of the classes seem very significant and are all hard to control
> There's no storyline
> It's hard as balls to get play
> There are other reasons, but other reviewers seem to have covered them pretty damn well

><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><

I admit that I haven't played all that much of the game, but from what I COULD all I discovered that it is immensly easy to die and is almost insanely hard to get even a single power up.  Also most of the Abilities" you can get have no explanation and don't seem to affect anything upon use.  There's not even a stat menu to see if any of the power ups have changed them.

And did I mention how easy it is to die?  Most of the beginning weapons barely have any effect on the enemies sometimes and it's almost like you lose health way too fast in some encounters.  You can survive for a much longer time in the Binding of Isaac compared to this game.  Not only that
date: but everytime you die it doesn't even feel like you've accomplished anything.  I know the point of a Rogue-Like is that you only have one life to do everything
recommended:
but this game takes that aspect way too seriously that it feels pointless to even try.

As for the storyline... well... WHAT STORYLINE?

I don't know who I am
hoursPlayed: where I'm going
voteText: or what I'm even doing this for.  There's really no point in doing whatever "Mission" I'm trying to do if there's no real goal in mind.  I'd say to get this game if it had a great storyline despite the weird and often annoying gameply
helpfulPercent: but since it doesn't even have THAT then I don't recommend that anyone really get this.\n\nThe only redeeming feature are the graphics
votesHelpful: and while I admire that
votesTotal: it takes a bit more than fancy creatures and pixel guns to make a game work.\n\n3/10 Would only play again since I paid for it"

reviewerDisplayName: v a p o r w a r e z
reviewText:
Early Access Review

Pretty much first-person-shooter Binding of Issac. It's the same bomb-tossing boss-fighting projectile-dodging roguelite system that made BoI so much fun. Being in 3D, however, means that you've got one more axis with which to dodge projectiles, and that makes the game too easy. Most bosses and rooms can be cleared by bunny-hopping around your enemies in circles and firing.

Were this a finished game, I would not recommend it. It's fun for only a short while in its current state. Because I'm anticipating more content and more refined mechanics, I'll let it slide as a loose recommendation.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nIf you like speed-run games, this is the game for you. The music playing in the background is very fastpaced, as it is techno,  making the gameplay very fastpaced. This game plays as a run-and-gun, where you go into separate rooms and they will start to branch off from there. The doors lock until you kill all of the enemies, so you cannot flee.There are normal rooms, boss rooms, and gift shops, where you use the gold you earned from the enemies you killed. There are also a few classes to be chosen from, but since this is an alpha, there are not many. For an alpha, this is a great game (in my opinion). Worth the money and will become addicting as you will want to play more and more.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

At first, I was pretty skeptical about what this game might be. A game that claims to mix the gameplay of Doom and Quake with the roguelike aspects of games like The Binding of Isaac? There's gotta be some major patchwork to be done in this game. And it's true, there DOES need to be additional content to be added. Right now, at the time of writing this (January 2014), this game is very much still a barebones basic game (and I'm not talking graphically).

The gameplay is very satisfying. The level design is random each and every time, so it's got one part of its description on the store page right. It IS like The Binding of Isaac in that way. The randomly generated levels and mix of enemies gives one a feeling of helplessness and unaware of what will come next. Bosses are fairly tough, and defeating one, depending on which character you play, is actually quite rewarding. For example, fighting a boss as Gilead is very different than fighting that same boss as The Tank.

The character stats, however, are not very balanced. At least all the characters have similar stats, and there's no real pros and cons to choosing one over the other. Out of the ten times I played, I chose Gilead 7 times and The Tank 3 times. Now, while this doesn't exactly seem like a good sample size, you can just look up the character stats online. All of them are fairly even and not balanced at all. I suspect this will get fixed in future patches and updates, and I do hope it does, because if these are actually the final character stats, I can't see myself playing this game much longer.

Back to the gameplay, the FPS integration is absolutely wonderful. A slightly minimalist HUD, simple weapons, great gunplay. These are the cores of any FPS game in my opinion if you want a good mix of immersion and good gameplay. There's nothing really much to say on the guns and the FPS aspects themselves other than I AM very much reminded of Quake and Doom in the level design, specifically with the wide open spaces you often encounter in the many rooms you'll be running and gunning through.

Overall, I give Paranautical Activity a 7.5/10. For an Early Access game, it's actually pretty well done. The level design, gameplay, and integration of two vastly different genres are definitely what I found to be unique about the game. However, as with most Early Access games, be wary: developers can just stop updating at any time they please. Vote with your wallet and read reviews like this one first before you purchase!
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Is there actually any other game where you fight a whale boss? If so, please recommend me one, because thus far no other game has pulled it off other than Paranautical Activity, that I know of.

This game is spectacular, in my eyes. It's not just because of the shiney voxels, The Binding of Isaac-inspired randomly-generated rooms, the way I gasp in joy as I receive a pile of gold from a slain enemy, the wobbles and wabbles of the dubstep soundtrack, or the fact that there's a David Bowie class -- no, I'm being serious.

Despite being denied the previlage to be put on Steam because of the whole adultswim business, Parantautical Activity proudly pulls off what you would call a Binding of Isaac FPS, if you just add lots of shiney lights, weird but freakishly cool creatures, dubstep and voxel-based graphics.

Definitely try this game out, it's truly an experience, indeed.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Pretty much first-person-shooter Binding of Issac. It's the same bomb-tossing boss-fighting projectile-dodging roguelite system that made BoI so much fun. Being in 3D, however, means that you've got one more axis with which to dodge projectiles, and that makes the game too easy. Most bosses and rooms can be cleared by bunny-hopping around your enemies in circles and firing.

Were this a finished game, I would not recommend it. It's fun for only a short while in its current state. Because I'm anticipating more content and more refined mechanics, I'll let it slide as a loose recommendation.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nIf you like speed-run games, this is the game for you. The music playing in the background is very fastpaced, as it is techno,  making the gameplay very fastpaced. This game plays as a run-and-gun, where you go into separate rooms and they will start to branch off from there. The doors lock until you kill all of the enemies, so you cannot flee.There are normal rooms, boss rooms, and gift shops, where you use the gold you earned from the enemies you killed. There are also a few classes to be chosen from, but since this is an alpha, there are not many. For an alpha, this is a great game (in my opinion). Worth the money and will become addicting as you will want to play more and more.

reviewText:
It's back, and Now I shall review it. it's a rogue-lite fps with multiple characters that determine starting conditions, many items to att abilities or change gameplay, from the simple goodness of faster fire-rate to the absurdity of vvvvvvv style gravity flipping. That said, it suffers from the same things rogue-lites all suffer from, such as repetitive gameplay and fiendish difficulty, but then again, games like this are supposed to be taken in bites.

every floor ends in a boss, and there are several unique bosses requiring different strategies, and then you move on to the next floor with an item belonging to that boss.

All things considered, I recommend it for the price tag and fun gameplay, so long as the game's rather troubled past doesn't spoil things for you. I had fun playing it, and if you like rogue-lites, rogue-likes, and other such ilk, you'll find this easier to enjoy than many others in that category.

Early Access Review

They advertised co-op as a coming feature to get sales from people looking for a fun co-op game, and then they drop support for it. You can get a little fun playing this on your own for a while, but it gets boring very quickly. Remind me to not support this dev in the future.

Edit - Steam says I have 0 hours on record for this game, but I only played it for 20 minutes because I wanted to save the game to play with friends when co-op is released. That's the way it goes though I guess.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Game is quite linear but really shines in many areas. It's face paced shooting really gives it an edge, expecially with the limited ammount of lives every shot counts and you've got to time everything. The game has some really nice animations, but a few could use some work. The game is an early access game and doesnt have all its features. I honestly believe that if you enjoy face paced, first person shooters that bring you to the edge of your seat then I reccomend this. It's a classic FPS with great features that you can really enjoy.

reviewText:
Do you like twitch shooters? Do you like games where you die a lot? Are you cool with having only one main weapon(which can be switched with other weapons if you find them)? Are you crazy for voxel graphics? Are you willing to accept or even enjoy a game with elements of randomness in which bosses you will fight, and which unlocks you will get? Are you cool with games with no story whatsoever?
Do you like games with levels and a boss at the end of each?

Answer yes" to most of these

reviewText:
This game looks so good untill you play it for more then 2 minutes. I really did try to enjoy it as i can ee how it could be fun, but sadly the game is just way to difficuit to be fun! Here are the pros and cons:

Pros:
[] Fun pixel design
[] Great music
[] Lots of rooms and weapons
[] Classes

Cons:
[] Enemy attaks you can't avoid
[] Boss attacks you can't avoid
[] Rooms are very dark
[] Hard to earn coins
[] VERY easy to die on a great run, no matter how much health!
[] Game is just way to hard in general

In my opinion this game needs more work and should still be in early access

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Edit 2: I actually beat all the bosses a while ago on the first try, but stopped there because the game just didn't feel like much fun.

What could be a great game is ruined by class imbalance, difficulty in aiming with certain guns as you dodge enemy bullets and lack of information on boss attack patterns.

Heres a small example of why this game sucks:

You are playing with a 3/3 HP class, boss has a lot of health, you haven't got upgrades or double jump because the game is just starting, you already used your few bombs on another boss. The boss spawns 5 spiders that quickly come at you while the boss keeps shooting fast travel speed bullets at you... and it keeps doing that until you are dead. So you have to move and aim around a small room with hill-like object placement, forcing you to stay rather close to the boss, but because the boss shoots with fast moving bullets, you can't dodge all of it because you also have to focus on evading and killing spiders, ESPECIALLY if you are using a single target, slow weapon

http://paranautical-activity.wikia.com/wiki/Skullito

Here's another frustrating example:

You complete stage 2 and pick up a powerup that decrease your speed but increases your damage.

The next boss you meet hits you for 5 damage (5x1 quick hits because he's so fast) every time after he casts his special attack because you are too slow to run from him, even if you are running from one end to another, or around the walls.. it takes you 20 hits to kill him, but before you can do that, he's already killed you in 3 combo attacks. like, wtf seriously

http://paranautical-activity.wikia.com/wiki/Hanz <---

7/10, would not recommend at the moment.
voteText: 4 of 10 people (40%) found this review helpful

reviewText: unbalanced, mismatched, and unfair game, i bought this because i love old school shooters and rouglike games so this game was an easy choice but when i started it up i died within 5 seconds. Okay... ill try again and realized that this game can be incredibly unfair espicially with the shark enemies that not only travel faster than all the characters, but the fact you literally have to stare straight down to shoot them kinda takes away the fun. This game does shooting and movement very well similar to quake 3 but its rooms are crammed with so much stuff  i cannot freeley move 3 feet without knowing EXACTLY how the room is set up. The weapons are also poorly matched with the stats on the characters, are not fun to use, and frankly useless with more interesting characters locked behind ridiculous challenges that only a die hard fan of a $10 arcade game ( probably not common ) can achieve, developer is also a jerk so yeah, don't buy this.

reviewText: First off big rep to Mike and Travis for this thrilling fast paced voxel shooter, everything i enjoyed from the music, to pace of the game, and even the feel is perfect for the content it has. Glad Steam brought it back it deserves it. I say it is worth the money it is priced at but I myself like sales so I waited for a great deal on it. Dont just listen to all the haters reviews because if they took a second to take the game for what it is instead of staying up Gabens ♥♥♥, then maybe people would see it is a very enjoyable experience for the casual and hardcore fps player. Kudos again guys and look forward to other projects from Code Avarice. 9/10

Ok this game is INSANE, and I MEAN INSANE IN A GOOD WAY! This has to be the most toughest and yet addicting games I have ever played in a while.

You start out with a selection of people to play as and then off you go, no explaining, no story, just go out there, kick some @$$ and DON'T DIE. The monsters are weird as hell even as voxels, and the Bosses are a BIT.CH to kill, but once you kill them, gives you that really good feeling that you kicked that boss real good in the @$$... But it gets worst from there. More and more of those bloody bast*rds get more crazy, more strong and what not. When you die, you don't want to quit, you just want to keep playing to get to a higher level than last time you died. The use of RPG elements is actually workable as well. Gives you a bit of those other games with RPG Elements like Saints Row 4, Wolfenstien, Bulletstorm and so on.

Music is amazing, mostly the song that plays in the trailer. When I heard that, it made me scream DIE DIE DIE YOU F***ING BLOODY BAST*RDS!!!" with a side of Dubstep with that.

Quality of the game is like that of Minecraft meets Doom
date: it just sounds awesome even saying that... well when I think of it.\n\nSo overall
recommended: it's a blood bath orgy of fun. Music: Awesome. Graphics: Nice. Monsters: @$$holes... But still fun. Game in general: Awesome Sauce Overload.\n\nThe one thing I would like for them to add is some Achievments
hoursPlayed: some sort of leaderboard to show how far you got
voteText: and some Steam Trading Cards
helpfulPercent: just for the hell of it. Plus the game is still in a Early Access so I bet the company that made this will add some stuff like that in the late future.\n\nYes Or No Verdict? F*** Yes
votesHelpful: get it."

reviewText:
This game fails on pretty much every level.

Firstly, the concept: It's basically a bullet-hell game in-first person, giving you an incredibly poor idea of where you are in relation to all the projectiles that are incoming from every angle and making it distressingly common that you sidestrafe into an obstacle, get stuck and eat a face full of projectile salvo.

Secondly, the graphical/UI design: Pretty much everything that isn't a projectile is the same colour of shadowy gray-ish mess, meaning that about the only way to spot enemies is their glowing eyes(when they have them), which are obscured by the helpful volleys of glowing projectiles all over the damn place.

Thirdly, it's a high-paced, dodging-heavy shooter... in a game where every single area is a cramped cube often further obstructed by stairs and similar. This one should speak for itself.

And then there are just all the gameplay issues. For instance, on the third level I encounter a melee-attacking boss who moves so fast that even at constant sprint away from him, even bunny-hopping, he constantly catches up with me and hits me. There's literally no way to avoid damage, hitting him doesn't slow him down, Nothing does. Your only hope of beating him is that your damage output and soaking ability beats his, which is entirely down to what pickups you've been lucky enough to get.

Did anyone ever playtest this? Or did they just slap a bunch of things together and go: FAST-PACED MUSIC. PIXEL ARTSTYLE. IT'S A WINNER."?

The music's pretty nice
recommended: so there is that.\n\n(Also why would you saddle one of the playable options with a melee weapon when every single enemy is either charging towards you to make its own melee attacks or constantly vomiting bullets? It's impossible to use it without taking damage.)"

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI like this game because it combines many things: Doom, The Binding of Isaac, and FPS. This game is very difficult and rogue-like, but it is still very fun and you should give it a try. You can play as multiple classes, such as Gilead, David Bowie, Dy-No-Mite!, The Tank, and Gorton. Some people say they don't like it because of the blocky look, but in my opinion, it looks cool. In this game you try to progress through floors, collecting money to buy powerups, weapons, etc. from the Gift Shop. You can also get items from bosses. The floors become harder as you progress.
